label: Telegraph from Sidney Jennings Legendre, April 6, 1945
description: Letter from Sidney Legendre to his wife, Gertrude Sanford Legendre, regarding her return to the continental United Sates after her internment as a prisoner of war in Europe. Sidney continues on in his letter to day dream of her being able to join him in Hawaii and the possibility of the family living there after the war and requesting that she visit Medway Plantation. He also discusses her prisoner of war escape into Switzerland.

metadata.value:

April 6, 1945
That was really wonderful talking to you last
night. It seemed so natural again to be hearing your voice
and laughing at what you said that the months in between
were anything of the past.I could only think of the wonderful
days ahead of us, the fun of being together again and enjoying
the same pleasures, living the same life.
I laughed so when you said that you felt so
badly about not having come back for my leave. As if you had
any choice in the matter; a prisoner in a camp really cannot
decide when to leave and to return, unless it is a prison camp
in America. I suppose you read about the German camp when all
the town girls in the little Western town use to go out and
stay with the German soldiers because they said they more
better physical specimens than the American boys. It caused
quite a scandal and I believe some Congressman made a speech
about morality. 
Your voice sounded very crisp and efficent
when we started talking and I was enomously reassured because
I knew for certain thou that you would take over everything
now,and when this war is over,in order that I may lay in the
sun all day long and pleasure myself. I would give anything
to see you. Long ago in the dim days I remember you weighed
125 pounds and were quite the loveliest girl in the world. I 
cant remember why you weighed so little but it seems to me that
you had just come hack from some expdition. We were in New 
York and you use to wear a black and white silk print dress
and your waist was the size of a thimble. Then suddenly you
went up to 127 lbs. and stayed there ever since. A terrific
weight but one that you carried very well. I would give any
thing to be there new and take you in my arms and tell you how
much I love you, how much I have missed and worried about you
dear. Once when we were stuck in Baghdad we said how wonderful
it would be if you could suddenly be transported from the dis-
comforts of an expedition to the Ritz wilhout the necks of ever
increasing comfortsin between. That is how I feel now. If
I could only be with you for these first marvellous days instead
of having to go through the slow process of picking up our
life again via letters and finally seeing one another after
months have-passed. You may even go up to one hundred and
twenty seven again before I do see you.
Of course I am awaiting with great eagerness
the details of your escape. How it was planned and the execution
of all arrangements. The newspaper said that you came out 
of the country dressed in your uniform. If it was the same
[End Page 1]
one that you went into the country with it must have been just
a tiny weenie bit high by the time you made your exit.
A further thought is that now that you know how
to make potatoe soup you will fill a long needed post in our
menage. None of use know how to make a good soup. As soon as
you arribe out here we will turn over the kitchen and the soup
pot to your capable hands [don't cheat and bring Rose] and even
might let you take care of the aprtment. Water the flowers
on the pent house roof, sweep the porch and generally busy
yourself around in a frau like manner. Think of the wonderful
clothes you can wear. All sorts of gay prints and backless
dresses. Bathing suits with big red hibiscus all over them,
and flowers in your hair. You will be as brown as an indian
in two days and on the third day through special dispensation
I will let you take out my surf board. I have not taken it
out for a year myself because I am too lazy, but still I will
act as if it is a special privilege. In the evening we will
dance to Hawaiian music, drink a moderate amount of gin fizzes
and fall asleep by nine, this being the latest hour on record
that anyone has [illegible] me on my feet.
I really believe you can get out here now darling.
Rules have been relaxed since we last tried and now Red Cross
workers, women correspondents, war workers, and wives of war
workers pour out. They still have the rule about the wives of
Navy officers not being allowed but I really think that only
applies to women who just come out as a wife. I met a girl
the other evening who is a lt [jg] in the SPARS and her husband
is out here. She said that when she told them she wanted to
be stationed out here because her husband was she met no
opposition whatsoever. It would be so marvellous to have
you here and at the same time we could decide whether you would
like to make this your home for the remainder of your natural
life [no haunting allowed.]. With aeroplane transportation after
the war one will be able to go back and forth so easily that
this is the ideal spot due to the wonderful climate, beauty of
the scenery and ease of life. I must warn you however that
I know no one out here so please do not come and think that
you are going to enter into a whirl of social activity, or that
my friends will be able to show you the best places to live or
advise you as to the charmes of the place. Margaret Emerson
is the head of the Red Cross or something out here, but I have
onlyseen her once and that has been my sole social contact.
Anyway that will permit you to start at scratch without any
obligations. In a precious letter I told you that George
Vanderbitls place was for sale and that I thought is was lovely
situated on the sea etc. However since then Morris tells me
that he saw an even more attractive house so you see how easily
one can change and how careful one must be in deciding these
important things.
[End Page 2]
If you have the  opporutnity, go down to theplantation
and see how it strikes you after your long absence. Henry says
it is wonderful, the flowers are out and the place is full of
spring and sunshine. However I cannot imagine what you could
do there for more than two days. If you are able to fly down
and back I think it would be well worth while just for
the rest and the added feeling that you are back again. If
I could only ride with you through those woods again, see the
sunshine on the golden brown grass, hear the mocking birds in
the wisteria arbor in the moonlight I would really feel that
you were back. This way it is only letter wrting, trying to 
tell you how much I love you without giving either of us the
satisfaction of looking into on anothers eys and smiling, of 
hearing all the little things that go to make up great
happiness.
With this letter go all the carbon copies of precious
letters written to you since you capture. You will note that
many copies are missing. This is because I failed to make 
copies fo these letters and only had an original. However I
do not feel that this really matters because what I have written
about has long ago passed and is finished in a way, although
at the same time it really lives on because I always seem to
write about the sunshine and flowers and the charm of the life
out here.
I do not know if you are aware of the fact that you
organization never told me that you had been captured until
a month afterwards when the radio had announced that you had
been taken. Naturally I had gone over to them to ask where
you were when you did not show up as you had promised. They said
they would send a cable to London to find out, then they said
London replied they had no record of you since you had left
them. All the time the louses knew you had dissappeared. The
next I heard about you was the letter from Marion Hall and then
silience until your organization told me via their representative
that it was thought you had escaped. The same day Jo Jo Hunghes
called me and said that you had escaped. The crowning event
was when their representative announced that a package was 
arriving xxxxx for me in Washington. I was sort of stupid at
first and asked from where and who sent it but he would only
say the abbve. I finally caught on, but must admit that all this
secrecy seemed a little far fetched since the papers were 
full of it.
Listen sweeheart, keep all these letters and clippings,
and we will put them in a big book and in the years hereafter
look through it and think of the days when we were seperated
and how happy we are to be togehter again.
All my love, an please please write, I have for-
gotten what you handwritting looks like.
[End Page 3]
